item.title: Abraham Stroschein
item.description: Abe is a second-year student at St. Thomas, currently pursuing a degree in Computer Engineering. His current responsibility is architecting and developing Python code for the COVG amplifier project. Abe is a receipient of a UST Science, Mathematics, and Engineering scholarship.

item.title: Corissa Uberecken
item.description: Corissa is a second year student majoring in Computer Engineering with a plan to study abroad. In the research lab during the summer of 2021 she became the group expert on the Texas Instruments ADS8686 ADC and brought up a development board using the part.

item.title: Ian Bonequi Delgadillo
item.description: Ian is a third year student at St. Thomas, pursuing a degree in Electrical Engineering. His current responsibility is developing Verilog code for the COVG amplifier project. Currently, he is using MATLAB to create real-time fixed-point filters that process ADC data to create outgoing data for the DACs. He has developed and tested modules that connect to a host computer using the Opal Kelly Front Panel interface, which allow the host computer to control analog to digital and digital to analog converters, through the use of an SPI interface and a Wishbone bus.

item.title: Nathan LoPresto
item.description: Nathan is a second year student majoring in Computer Engineering. In the research lab he developed user facing Python code for viewing ADC waveforms and interacting with the COVG DAQ system. He has also been the hands-on teaching assistant for the Introduction to Electrical and Computer Engineering course.

item.title: William Schneider
item.description: Will, a sophomore from a small town in central Minnesota, is studying mechanical engineering and researching the electrical properties of conductive filaments for 3D printers. His primary interest is horology, but he also finds 3D printers, RC systems, and high powered rockets interesting. He codes well (even in C++)!

item.title: William Schneider
item.description: Will, a 3rd year student from a small town in central Minnesota, is studying mechanical engineering and researching the electrical properties of conductive filaments for 3D printers. His primary interest is horology, but he also finds 3D printers, RC systems, and high powered rockets interesting. He codes well (even in C++)!

item.title: Jakob Porter
item.description: Jake Porter is a 3rd year undergraduate student majoring in Electrical Engineering. He has contributed to the analog and PCB design aspects of the NIH COVG project. He is diving into switch mode DC/DC converters and analog feedback loops, while also learning KiCAD. In 2021 Jake was an MIAC All-Conference outfielder for the St. Thomas baseball team!

item.title: Ian Bonequi Delgadillo
item.description: Ian is a second-year student at St. Thomas, currently pursuing a degree in Electrical Engineering. His current responsibility is developing Verilog code for the COVG amplifier project. He is coding modules that will connect to a host computer using the Opal Kelly Front Panel interface, which allow the host computer to control analog to digital and digital to analog converters, through the use of an SPI interface and a Wishbone bus.
